threat_description: False location data is injected into logistics systems to disguise the real-time position of goods.

motives.motive: Financial gain through cargo theft and smuggling

components.name: Navigation and Positioning Systems
components.description: A maritime navigation tool that integrates GPS, AIS, and radar for accurate positioning.

cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Attackers can exploit the lack of validation in GPS and AIS signals to inject false positioning data, misleading vessels about their actual location. This can cause ships to drift off-course, increasing the risk of collisions, illegal rerouting for smuggling, or hijackings. Cybercriminals may also create phantom vessels to mask illicit activities.

The absence of strong encryption and authentication mechanisms in GPS and AIS transmissions allows attackers to intercept and modify vessel positioning data. This can be used to redirect ships into dangerous waters, disrupt fleet coordination, or facilitate cargo theft by misrepresenting ship locations.

Since AIS data is publicly available and lacks proper access controls, attackers can inject false information to create fake ship identities, manipulate shipping manifests, or hide illegal maritime activities. Spoofing AIS signals can also lead to fleet coordination disruptions and increased operational risks.

Weak access controls in vessel navigation systems allow unauthorized modifications to positioning data. Attackers can override course settings, disable tracking, or falsify ship locations, making it easier to hijack vessels, smuggle goods, or evade authorities.

GPS jamming attacks involve broadcasting interference signals that overwhelm a vessel’s navigation system, preventing accurate positioning. This can cause ships to lose situational awareness, leading to navigational errors, delays, or forced rerouting into high-risk areas.

Weak or default authentication credentials in shipboard communication systems allow attackers to gain unauthorized access to navigation and control networks. This can lead to remote route manipulation, disabled tracking mechanisms, or ransom-driven disruptions to vessel operations.

motives.motive: Delay or reroute vessel docking for economic disruption

components.name: Core Maritime Subsystem
components.description: Manipulating berthing systems can delay port entry, impact scheduling, or increase demurrage fees for targeted vessels.

cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: This CWE supports the motive by enabling unauthorized manipulation of core systems.
Weak authentication may allow adversaries to impersonate internal components.
Improper validation allows injection or tampering that aligns with the motive.

cwes.cwe_id: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')
cwes.cwe_mapping_reason: Attackers may inject visual or control-layer spoofing to support manipulation.
SQL injection enables unauthorized read/write to manifest or tracking data.
Poor secret management exposes authentication material usable in further attacks.
